name: The Family & Youth Institute
mission: Redefining the narrative on Muslim mental health and well-being and championing a world where individuals, families, and communities are empowered and flourishing.
theoryOfChange: The Family & Youth Institute explicitly states 'the fyi's theory of change' within their 'Research' section. Their approach is described as a community-based participatory research model that ensures community voices and experiences drive their research. This involves partnering with communities to pinpoint priorities, exploring research questions, identifying wellness needs, and addressing concerns within faith and cultural contexts. They engage and integrate community voices throughout the research process, incorporate community perspectives on data, identify practical solutions, and share the benefits. Their mission is to strengthen and empower individuals, families, and communities through research and education, working to shift narratives and promote mental health and well-being.
zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://thefyi.org/zakat (Source: https://thefyi.org/zakat)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Limited match due to weaker results and/or higher uncertainty; review methodology details before deciding.

components.improvement_suggestion: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.

all_citations.claim: The FYI focuses on research and education for youth development and family health.
The organization reported total revenue of $850,837, a program expense ratio of 83.6%, fundraising efficiency of $0.09 per $1 raised, and 23.6 months of working capital.
The organization offers various donation options and giving methods for supporters.
The Family and Youth Institute is zakat-eligible and maintains a specific zakat policy.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a 60/100 reflecting strong financial efficiency and specialized community impact, though the overall score is tempered by low data confidence and a lack of external ratings.
areas_for_improvement: Limited third-party impact evaluations or external performance ratings
Low data confidence due to limited publicly available documentation beyond basic financial filings

dimension_explanations.alignment: With an alignment score of 29/50, the charity offers a medium fit for donors interested in advocacy and mental health within a community context [1]. The organization is explicitly zakat-eligible, providing clear policies on how these funds are utilized to support eligible categories [3][4].
dimension_explanations.impact: The FYI demonstrates high operational effectiveness by maintaining a program expense ratio of 83.6% and focusing on capacity building through mental health research [1][2]. While the organization shows strong financial health with 23.6 months of working capital, the impact score of 36/50 reflects a need for more robust evidence of long-term outcomes [2].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Family and Youth Institute strengthens community well-being through research-backed mental health initiatives and educational programming.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 83.6% ensures the majority of funds directly support research and education
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with a cost of only $0.09 per $1 raised
Strong liquidity position with 23.6 months of working capital available
Verified zakat-eligible status for donors seeking to fulfill religious obligations
baseline_narrative.summary: The Family and Youth Institute (The FYI) is a research and education organization dedicated to promoting positive youth development and healthy family dynamics [1]. Operating with a total revenue of $850,837, the organization provides specialized resources such as the Aging with Dignity Project and community education workshops [2].

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization currently operates with a <cite id="13">board of only two members</cite>, which presents risks regarding oversight and long-term institutional sustainability.
There is a <cite id="14">lack of consistent beneficiary data</cite> available, making it difficult to calculate specific cost-per-beneficiary metrics.

case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="13">governance risks</cite> and <cite id="15">limited public transparency</cite>.

confidence.notes: While financial efficiency is high, the low data confidence score reflects a lack of external transparency seals and a small governing board.

alignment.explanation: The FYI is a strong fit for Muslim donors, offering <cite id="16">verified zakat eligibility</cite> and serving the <cite id="17">fisabilillah asnaf category</cite> through community education.
alignment.improvement: The organization could improve alignment by <cite id="18">clarifying its specific zakat allocation policy</cite> and eligible use categories for donors.

credibility.explanation: Donors can find confidence in the organization's <cite id="10">national recognition and White House citations</cite>. However, credibility is currently constrained by <cite id="15">low data confidence (0.3)</cite> and a <cite id="13">two-member board</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the organization should <cite id="13">expand its board of directors</cite> to include more independent members and pursue a full rating from Charity Navigator.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by a <cite id="5">high program expense ratio of 83.6%</cite> and a <cite id="9">strong theory of change</cite>. The organization effectively uses its <cite id="12">$850,837 in revenue</cite> for capacity building.
impact.improvement: Impact measurement would benefit from <cite id="14">publishing consistent beneficiary counts</cite> to allow for cost-effectiveness benchmarking.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade B - Documented Theory of Change with external recognition

rich_narrative.headline: The Family and Youth Institute strengthens community well-being through research-backed mental health initiatives and educational programming.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who value intellectual investment and want to fund research-backed solutions for the unique mental health challenges facing Muslim families in the West.
donor_motivations: Want to support the development of culturally sensitive mental health resources
Value research and data-driven approaches to community education
Seek to fulfill zakat through educational and advocacy-based asnaf
Prefer funding lean organizations with high program-to-overhead ratios
giving_considerations: The organization is in a growth stage with a small governing board
Impact is measured through knowledge production rather than direct service delivery
Financial transparency is currently limited to basic tax filings
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking large-scale international humanitarian relief or those who require rigorous third-party financial audits before giving.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade B reflects a strong internal theory of change and significant external recognition from government and media, though missing independent RCTs.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The FYI creates impact by conducting original research on Muslim mental health and translating those findings into community workshops and toolkits that empower families.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that mental health interventions are culturally appropriate and effective for the target demographic.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: As a small research institute with a $850k budget, additional funding is critical to expanding their research team and geographic workshop reach.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by its <cite id="10">academic research focus</cite> and national-level policy influence.

strengths.detail: The organization directs <cite id="5">83.6% of its total expenses</cite> toward its research and education programs, exceeding industry benchmarks for non-profit efficiency.
The FYI demonstrates high fiscal discipline, spending only <cite id="7">$0.09 to raise every $1</cite> in contribution revenue.
The charity maintains <cite id="8">23.6 months of working capital</cite>, providing a significant buffer for long-term project stability.

strengths_deep_dive: The Family and Youth Institute distinguishes itself through a <cite id="9">documented theory of change</cite> that bridges the gap between academic research and community practice. Their expertise has gained significant recognition, having been <cite id="10">quoted at the White House</cite> and featured in national media outlets. Financially, the organization is on a stable trajectory with a <cite id="11">3-year revenue CAGR of 6.1%</cite>, supported by a diverse revenue stream where <cite id="12">contributions totaled $806,832</cite> in the most recent tax year. This growth allows for the continued expansion of niche programs like the Aging with Dignity Project, which addresses underserved needs within the community.
rich_narrative.summary: The Family and Youth Institute (The FYI) is a research-focused non-profit organization that strengthens community well-being through <cite id="1">evidence-based mental health initiatives and educational programming</cite>. Founded in <cite id="2">2006</cite>, the organization addresses critical gaps in social science research specifically tailored to the needs of Muslim families. With <cite id="3">total revenue of $850,837</cite>, The FYI operates as a specialized capacity-builder, translating complex research into actionable community resources. Their work spans several key domains, including <cite id="4">youth development, marriage support, and the Aging with Dignity Project</cite>. The organization maintains a lean operational structure, ensuring that a <cite id="5">program expense ratio of 83.6%</cite> is directed toward its core mission of research and education. By providing <cite id="6">community education workshops and mental health research</cite>, The FYI serves as a vital intellectual hub for the American Muslim community, addressing sensitive topics such as domestic violence, substance abuse, and intergenerational conflict with cultural sensitivity and academic rigor.
